record.creator: Vanderbilt Department of History of Art

record.site_data: 安禅寺 山西省, 普中市，太谷县 Ānchánsì ZGWWDTJ, Shanxi vol. 3 (xia), p. 762 57 – C 1 (On Anchansi street in Taigu County Seat• Song, Ming dynasties •Provincial Cultural Heritage Site) Date of initial founding unknown. According to an inscription, the complex was rebuilt in the Song dynasty, with repairs made in the Yuan and Ming dynasties as well as in the third year of the Qing Guangxu reign period (1877). The complex occupies 200 square meters. Buildings are oriented to the south, the monastic cloister has been destroyed, all that remains are two axial buildings, the Sutra Repository (Cángjīngdiàn (藏经殿)) and the Main Hall (Zhèngdiàn (正殿)). Of the remaining buildings, the Sutra Repository is a artifact of the Song dynasty; the Main Hall is a Ming dynasty building. The front façade of the Main Hall is 3 bays in width with a depth of 6 rafters, and has a single eaves, overhanging gable roof, 7 purlin-no gallery style design, 3-step, single ang bracket sets (sancai danang 三踩单昂), with one intercolumnar bracket set in each bay. Translated by Lydia Ohl; modified TM 7/28/10; 9/19/11; Edited by Cole Garrett 9/9/11;
record.building_data: Ānchánsì ZZWWDTJ, Shanxi vol. 3 (xia), p. 762 57 – C 1-1 Sutra Repository (cángjīngdiàn/藏经殿 (Song Dynasty)) Brick podium, front façade of 3 bays, depth of 3 bays, single eaves hip/gable roof, yellow and green glazed tiles with a square center, wide central bay and narrow side bays, central bay is only one half the width of the side bay. Under eave bracket sets are 4 pūzuò with a single huágŏng, a locust head shuătóu, 1 intercolumnar bracket set in every bay, and visible column-top entasis. Original renovation no longer exists. Translated by Lydia Ohl; modified TM 7/28/10; 9/19/11; Edited by Cole Garrett 9/9/11
record.comments_and_field_notes: sutra repository Song, compare to Jidumiao qingong
record.notes: ZGWWDTJ 山西 p. 762 57 – C 1 -other parts of the monastary have been destroyed

record.site_data: 白台寺 金至清 山西省，运城市， 新绛县 Băitáisì ZGWWDTJ, vol. 3 (xia), p.1099 126 – C 1, (About 200 meters southwest of Gujiao village in Guangma town•Jin and Yuan Dynasties•Provincial Cultural Heritage Site) (untranslated CG) Also called Pŭhuàsì (普化寺). Called Băitáisì (white seat temple) because legend holds Buddha’s lotus throne to be white. According to stele inscription,had many restorations in the fourtheenth year of Tang Kaiyuan (726)、and between the Jin Dading and Mingchang years, further restored in the first year of Zhizheng (1355) and the sixth year of Ming Zhengde (1511). Increase in construction in Qing Dynasty. Occupancy area of 4,482 square meters. Facing south, 2 entrance courtyard design, axial buildings include a sāndīfăcánggé (三滴法藏阁)， shìjiādiàn (释迦殿)， and a hòudàdiàn (后大殿)， on either side there is an east shānmén (山门） and a west wing. Within complex interior is preserved a Tang dynasty pagoda, a Song dynasty jīngchuáng(经幢) stone pillar with Buddhist inscriptions, a Song cloud board from the third year of Xuanhe (1121) , and 18 colored/painted walls. Translated by Lydia Ohl; edited by Cole Garrett
record.building_data: 白台寺 金至清 山西省，运城市， 新绛县 Băitáisì ZZWWDTJ, vol. 3 (xia), p.1099 126 – C 1-2 Shìjiādiàn (释迦殿) Jin Dynasty Rebuilt in Jin Mingchang years (1190-1194). Stone podium, according to topography and building, front is 0.75 meters tall, back is 0.3 meters tall, front façade of 3 bays, depth of 6 rafters, single eave hip gable roof , main roof ridge、vertical ridge、berm ridge and temple ridge are made of carved brick. Under eave column top bracket set have 4 pūzuò(铺作) and a single xia ang, be careful of inter columnar bracket sets. Internal beam composition of 4 rafters that connect to back with 3 columns, overturned basin shaped column base. Be careful of central bay door, other bays have lattice windows. Hall interior Buddhist altar presents 12 portraits of Buddha, Sakyamuni Buddha in the center, both sides have an Ananda (阿难)、Mahākāśyapa（迦叶）、bodhisattva (菩萨), under two gables there are 6 arahats, horizontal back wall has a portrait of Weituo (韦陀)，later generations have already changed the shape, their original characteristics have been lost. Translated by Lydia Ohl; revised by Cole Garrett
record.comments_and_field_notes: Shijiadian from Jin Mingchang period (1190-1196) see: 中國 文物 地圖集山西分冊, 下, 1099
record.notes: Axis: c, roof style: h/g, front façade: 31' 3",3 bays, side: 31' 4" 3 bays

record.building_data: 白台寺 金至清 山西省，运城市， 新绛县 Băitáisì ZGWWDTJ, vol. 3 (xia), p.1099 126 – C 1-1 Sāndīfăcánggé (三滴法藏阁) Yuan Dynasty Established in the Jin dynasty, restoration done in the Yuan dynasty. Building built by tŭyá (土崖), stone podium, 6.5 meters tall, centre opens into a rectangular passageway. Building has 2 floors, a front façade of 3 bays, depth of 6 rafters, triple eave overhanging gable roof, main ridge has open carved brickwork as a ridge decoration. Beam composition of 4 rafters that connect to the front with 3 columns, first floor has a balcony (píngzuò/平座), upper eave has a ring bracket sets all the way around, 5 pūzuò(铺作) single xia ang, 1 set of inter columnar bracket sets in every bay. Second story balcony has 4 shrines with Yaowang (药王) 、attendants， images in the East erdian of Dizang and Yanjun, both are severely damaged.
record.notes: Axis: c, roof style: o-g, front façade: 36' 5"

record.building_data: 白台寺 金至清 山西省，运城市， 新绛县 Băitáisì ZGWWDTJ, vol. 3 (xia), p.1099 126 – C 1-3 Hòudàdiàn (后大殿) Yuan Dynasty Built in the eleventh year of Yuan Zhiyuan(1274), stone podium 0.33 meters tall, front façade of 5 bays, depth of 6 rafters, single eave overhanging gable, carved brick roof ridge. Interior beam composition of 4 rafters that connect to the back with 3 columns, under eave bracket sets have 5 pūzuò （铺作） and a double xia ang, there are no inter columnar bracket sets. Be careful of front eave door, other two bays have lattice windows that later generations have improved，overturned basin style column base. Hall interior has a Buddhist altar, with a statue of Sakyamuni Buddha sitting in an elevated lotus flower shaped throne, there are Bodhisattva on either side to serve, portraits follow the Tang style. The front of the dàdiàn has a spacious platform, central part of the platform has a Tang dynasty pagoda with statues and streamers. Song dynasty people carved Buddhist inscriptions into each of the four corners pillars. 1 Song dynasty iron cloud stele. Translated by Lydia Ohl; revised by Cole Garrett.
record.notes: Axis: c, roof style: o-g, front façade: 60', side: 25' 9"

record.building_data: 白玉宫 山西省， 陵川县，晋城市 Báiyùgōng ZGWWDTJ, Shanxi vol 2 (zhong), 513 23－C 10-1 Zhèngdiàn（正殿） (Jin) stone podium, 0.8 meters tall, front facade of 3 bays depth of 4 rafters single eave hip/gable roof. interior beam composition of 3 rafters connecting to front eave with 3 columns, 4 puzuo column top bracket sets and a single xia ang, 1 inter-columnar bracket set in every bay, original door no longer exists. Translated by Lydia Ohl; edited by Cole Garrett

record.site_data: 兴梵寺 祁县 Xingfansi ZGWWDTJ Shanxi, vol. 3; p.775 33 – C 1 Date of founding unknown, building area of 287 square meters. Facing south, single courtyard design and the only extant building on the central axis is the main hall (大殿).
record.building_data: main hall (大殿). [The main hall] has a brick platform of 1.85 meters high, a front façade of 5 bays, with a depth of 6 rafters, and a single eave hip/gable roof. Internal beam structure is supported by four columns, with a 4-rafter beam connected to both the front and back column grid by a single-rafter beam (搭牵; 劄牵?). 4 puzuo bracket sets with a single huagong (杪), original restoration no longer exists. Translated by Lydia Ohl; revised by T Miller, 02-2017
record.comments_and_field_notes: Main Hall Song structure; see: 中國文物地圖集山西分冊, 下, 775
